results.title: Jewel of the Nile (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Lewis Teague, Michael Douglas and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Thrill-packed sequel to “Romancing the Stone”. It’s been six months since Joan Wilder (Kathleen Turner) and Jack Colton (Michael Douglas) sailed into the sunset after their first adventure - but it hasn’t all been smooth sailing. Then they learn of the mysterious, priceless Jewel of the Nile, and it’s non-stop excitement as they race to beat villainous Danny de Vito to the treasure.

results.title: Girls, girls, girls (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Norman Taurog, Hal B. Wallis and Wallis-Hazen
results.brief_description: Over a dozen Hollywood leading ladies, including Stella Stevens, star with Elvis Presley in this lighthearted musical about a nightclub singer who runs a fishing boat as a hobby. Songs featured include ‘Return to Sender’, ‘I Don’t Want To’, ‘Because of Love’ and ‘Song of the Shrimp’.

results.title: Three fugitives (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Francis Veber, Lauren Shuler and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Nick Nolte plays a tough ex-con, fresh out of prison, who is trapped in a bank and held hostage by a bungling, first-time holdup man (Martin Short). No one will believe Nolte’s innocence and no one can believe Short’s guilt, so the unlikely duo become partners in crime - and parenting, when Short’s six year old daughter joins the fugitives on a wheel-screeching run for the Canadian border. An American version of the successful French film of the same name.

results.title: Your body and its parts
results.creator_credit: David Bennett and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Life Science”.
Provides an overview of human physiology. Illustrates the body parts working together to do a job and forming a system. Introduces the muscular, respiratory, circulatory, skeletal and nervous systems.

results.title: The Plant
results.creator_credit: Thomas Vamos, Helene Verrier and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A live-action non-narrated story about a man who brings a plant, that had been struggling up through a crack in the pavement, into his apartment. The plant is lavished with kindness by its new owner, but has a mind of its own and soon grows out of control. It encroaches into all areas of the apartment, eventually damaging it beyond repair. An open-ended film allowing scope for language development.

results.title: Tadpoles and frogs
results.brief_description:
Captures the transformation of a tadpole into a frog. Covers each stage of development from observation and hatching of the tiny frog eggs up through the development of hind limbs and forelimbs.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: The Sun
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and Media Four Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Solar System”.
Provides a theory of how the sun was created and indicates its value to earth in terms of energy. Also gives some insight into the nature of the sun’s surface and the relationship between sunspots and weather patterns.

results.title: The Sexes: what's the difference?
results.creator_credit: Heather Cook, Roman Bittman and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Examines the question of whether or not there are certain basic biological differences between males and females. The assertion that the socialisation of children totally determines their social behaviour and attitudes is disputed. Environmental factors may not be the sole determinants of sex roles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Plants in action
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, Nicholas Alexander, Australian Academy of Science and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Time-lapse photography is used to show slow movement in plants such as the Venus flytrap, the albitsia tree, clover, daffodils, beans, fern fronds, climbing plants and water lilies. Provides an excellent means by which to convince children of something that is not readily accessible to the naked eye. Photography by Roger Seccombe and narration by Gerard Kennedy. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: On camera : The BBC video production course [kit]
results.creator_credit: Harris Watts, Mike Crisp and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This practical training course for film and video production consists of four videos, each with an accompanying booklet, and a teacher’s guide. 1. ‘The camera’ compares the camera’s view of the world with the human eye, considers focal length and angle of view, outlines the terminology for shot sizes and camera moves, shows how to maintain continuity of direction (34min). 2. ‘Planning a program’ introduces the basic techniques of recording an event on camera, suggesting ways of improving coverage by planning ahead (17min). 3. ‘Interviews’ looks at how to tackle interviews both inside and outside the studio and how to maintain the viewer’s interest (21min). 4. ‘Editing’ introduces principles to guide your selection, order and length of shots and shows how your decisions will affect the way the story is told (20min).
